conclusion: Understand the relationship between magnetic force on a current-carrying wire and Ampere force.
Ampere force formula: F = BIL, where B is magnetic field strength, I is current, and L is length of the wire.
Since the triangle is equilateral, all sides are equal, and the current is constant.
The magnetic field strength B is constant as it is uniform across the triangle.
The Ampere force on each section of the wire is the same because they are all in the same magnetic field.
The total Ampere force on the triangle is the sum of the forces on each section.
Since the triangle is equilateral, the total length L of the triangle is 3 times the side length.
The current I is constant, and since the triangle is symmetrical, the Ampere force on each section is F = BIL.
The total Ampere force on the triangle is F_total = 3 times F = 3 times BIL.
Given that the current I is constant, the total Ampere force F_total is also constant.
The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires at this time is 3 times BIL.
